title: Trimebutine
text:
Trimebutine is a drug with <a href="antimuscarinic">antimuscarinic</a> and weak <a href="mu%20opioid%20receptor">mu</a> <a href="opioid">opioid</a> <a href="agonist">agonist</a> effects. It is used for the treatment of <a href="irritable%20bowel%20syndrome">irritable bowel syndrome</a> and other gastrointestinal disorders.
The major product from <a href="drug%20metabolism">drug metabolism</a> of trimebutine in human beings is <a href="nortrimebutine">nortrimebutine</a>, which comes from removal of one of the methyl groups attached to the nitrogen atom. Trimebutine exerts its effects in part due to causing a premature activation of phase III of the <a href="migrating%20motor%20complex">migrating motor complex</a> in the digestive tract. <br>
Both trimebutine and its metabolite are commercially available.
Brand names.
The <a href="maleic%20acid">maleic acid</a> salt of trimebutine is marketed under the <a href="trademark">trademark</a>s of Antinime, Cineprac, Colospasmyl, Colypan, Crolipsa, Debricol, Debridat, Digedrat, Espabion, Gast Reg, Irritratil, Krisxon, Muttifen, Neotina, Polybutin, Sangalina, Trebutel, Tribudat, Tributina, Trim, Trimeb, Trimedat, and Trimedine.
